instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SSD_RESET_CONN_L: What is SSD_RESET_CONN_L? SSD_RESET_CONN_L is a signal that goes to the SSD that will put it in RESET mode which will keep it from working, when SSD_RESET_L is present. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
Arrived intermittently not booting from internal SSD. Liquid damage all around <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> area.

Replaced everything in the area but now cant boot from internal SSD at all now.

<CHIP>U3740</CHIP> pin 6 3.2V pin 7 1.358V pin 8 0V pin 3 3.2V

<CHIP>U3740</CHIP> has been replaced twice now. Is it possible both <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> are bad? Should something else be checked?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
Pin 7 should be steady 0V.
Check <RESISTOR>R3744</RESISTOR>/45 and all traces around.
Be sure to have good circuits to J3700.
Also check <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>/11.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message: what do you get on pin 4? be sure there are no broken traces too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R3744</RESISTOR> is no stuff on this board and on  a working board? <RESISTOR>R3745</RESISTOR> is good

<CHIP>U3710</CHIP>/11 3.3V

Pin 4 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R3744</RESISTOR>/45 must be present at same time on the board.
The other option is soldered <RESISTOR>R3743</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3744</RESISTOR>/45 not used any.

Alos, as MOMOH mentioned above, check if <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL> is high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
Do you have <RESISTOR>R3744</RESISTOR>/45 on the board, or just <RESISTOR>R3743</RESISTOR>?
Check all the C371x caps and traces around J3700.
Also clean the connector pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
Just <RESISTOR>R3743</RESISTOR>

Replaced all of the C371x caps just to rule out but no change.

Board has been through ultrasonic but no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message:
Ultrasonic bath can clean corroded areas.
But also can break some corroded traces; and will nor rebulid that!
You must be very careful, as an ultrasonic cleaner without sweep option can make more damages on the board.
You must re-check all traces continuity and small resistors.

"Just <RESISTOR>R3743</RESISTOR>
--------------
<RESISTOR>R3745</RESISTOR> is good"
What do you think?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SSD
threads.message: Solved. Board originally only had <RESISTOR>R3743</RESISTOR>. Removed <RESISTOR>R3743</RESISTOR> and put in its place <RESISTOR>R3744</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3745</RESISTOR>
